title: Can you transplant a head to another body? - Max G. Levy

multiple-choice.question: What was Robert White's ultimate goal with his experiment on connecting the head of Monkey A to the body of Monkey B?

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a new treatment for spinal cord injuries

options.label: C
options.text: To perform a whole-body transplant on humans

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of anesthesia on monkeys

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the technical hurdles faced by White's surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: Maintaining a constant supply of oxygenated blood to the brain

multiple-choice.question: Why did White develop a brain-cooling technique for his transplant surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: To slow down the brain's metabolism and reduce its reliance on oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: To speed up the brain's metabolism and increase its oxygen supply

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the risk of immune rejection

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of White's experiment on cooling the brain of a human patient with a life-threatening brain tumor?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient suffered debilitating pain and neurological damage

options.label: B
options.text: The patient's brain was successfully cooled into "suspended animation" at 11°C

options.label: C
options.text: The patient's tumor was not removed

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the serious ethical concerns raised by White's research?

options.label: A
options.text: The potential for debilitating pain and neurological damage

options.label: B
options.text: The number of animals that would have to die to prove the surgery was possible

multiple-choice.question: How did the scientific community react to White's research?

options.label: A
options.text: Many scientists strongly supported White's research

options.label: B
options.text: Many scientists recognized the cruelty of White's research and strongly opposed it

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of White's monkey body transplant experiment?

options.label: B
options.text: The monkey was paralyzed and extremely distressed

options.label: C
options.text: The monkey was able to move and function normally

options.label: D
options.text: The monkey's brain did not survive the transplant

multiple-choice.question: What does modern neuroscience suggest about the mind-body divide?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain plays a central role in building out our consciousness

options.label: B
options.text: The body plays a central role in building out our consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: The mind and body are separate entities

options.label: D
options.text: The mind-body divide is a myth

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the questions raised by White's surgery about the nature of life and the limits of science?

options.label: A
options.text: Is extending a life always worth the cost?

options.label: B
options.text: Can a person's head be transplanted onto a donor's body?

options.label: C
options.text: Is it possible to reconnect a severed spinal cord?

options.label: D
options.text: Can a person's brain be cooled into "suspended animation"?

multiple-choice.question: What was Robert White's profession?

options.label: B

options.text: Ancient Persia and Tang dynasty China

What was the result of the ban on the sale of alcohol in 1920 on many American saloons?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It limited the availability of ice cream

options.label: C
options.text: It made ice cream more accessible to the masses

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the availability of ice cream

title: How does an air conditioner actually work? - Anna Rothschild

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical efficiency of a heat pump compared to traditional heaters?
What percentage of global energy-related CO2 emissions was attributed to heating buildings in 2021?
How do heat pumps reduce emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: By burning fossil fuels more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: By running on electricity and using less energy to produce heat

options.label: C
options.text: By using more energy to produce heat

options.label: D
options.text: By releasing refrigerants into the atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: The same technology as air conditioners

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the refrigerant in a heat pump?

options.label: B
options.text: To transfer heat from one location to another

multiple-choice.question: What is the drawback of using hydrofluorocarbons as refrigerants?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not potent greenhouse gases

options.label: C
options.text: A single molecule can have 2,000 times the global warming impact of CO2

options.label: D
options.text: They are not effective at transferring heat

multiple-choice.question: Why do air-to-air heat pumps become less efficient in colder temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the refrigerant becomes more effective at transferring heat

options.label: B
options.text: Because the air is warmer than the refrigerant

options.label: C
options.text: Because the temperature difference between the air and the refrigerant decreases

options.label: D
options.text: Because the compressor and fans use more energy

multiple-choice.question: What is an alternative to air-to-air heat pumps in colder climates?

options.label: B
options.text: Drawing heat from under the ground

options.label: C
options.text: Using a different type of refrigerant

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of installing a heat pump?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more expensive than traditional heaters

options.label: B
options.text: It can save money on utilities in the long run

options.label: C
options.text: It is only suitable for small homes

options.label: D
options.text: It requires a lot of maintenance

multiple-choice.question: How do heat pumps appear to "break" the first law of thermodynamics?

options.label: B
options.text: By using their electricity to power the compressor and spin the fans, and getting extra energy from heat in the air or underground

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing refrigerants into the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: By burning fossil fuels more efficiently

title: Could AI predict the future? - Thomas Hofweber

multiple-choice.question: What is the context in which the speaker is considering using an AI-based model to predict the likelihood of divorce?

options.text: The speaker is considering getting engaged to their partner Alex.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker is a marriage counselor looking for tools to help their clients.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker is a software developer creating an app to predict divorce.

multiple-choice.question: What is the accuracy rate of the AI-based model in predicting divorce within the first five years of marriage?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only predict divorce within the first year of marriage.

options.label: B
options.text: It can only predict divorce for couples who have been together for more than five years.

options.label: C
options.text: It doesn't offer any reasons for its results.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only predict divorce for couples who have children.

options.label: A
options.text: Get married anyway, break up now, or stay together and remain unmarried.

options.label: B
options.text: Get married anyway, break up now, or seek counseling.

options.label: C
options.text: Get married anyway, stay together and remain unmarried, or seek counseling.

options.label: D
options.text: Break up now, stay together and remain unmarried, or seek counseling.

multiple-choice.question: What is the issue with AI models mentioned in the transcript that affects their usefulness?
How does the lack of transparency in AI models impact users?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them more accountable for their decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them less accountable for their decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on their accountability.

multiple-choice.question: What is the tradeoff mentioned in the transcript that users make when outsourcing important decisions to AI?
What is the potential consequence of relying solely on the AI model's prediction?

options.label: A
options.text: The couple may be able to avoid divorce.

options.label: B
options.text: The couple may be more likely to divorce due to a self-fulfilling prophecy.

options.label: C
options.text: The couple may be more likely to stay together.

options.label: D
options.text: The couple may be less likely to seek counseling.

multiple-choice.question: What does the 95% accuracy rate of the AI model mean in terms of false predictions?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: 1 in 20 couples will receive a false prediction.

options.label: C
options.text: 1 in 50 couples will receive a false prediction.

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 100 couples will receive a false prediction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate decision that the speaker emphasizes is still up to the individual?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether to get married or not.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether to use the AI model or not.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether to break up or not.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether to ask for the AI model's prediction or not.

title: What happened when these 6 dictators took over? - Stephanie Honchell Smith

options.label: B
options.text: He was attending a senate meeting

options.label: D
options.text: He was visiting a neighboring city

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of the "benevolent dictator"?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A leader who holds absolute power, yet only uses it for the common good

options.label: C
options.text: A leader who is elected democratically, but has limited power

options.label: D
options.text: A leader who is chosen by the people, but has no real authority

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: With members of the opposition party

options.label: D
options.text: With journalists who are free to criticize them

options.label: D
options.text: By refusing to acknowledge unfavorable election results

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That he was a popular leader among the people

options.label: B
options.text: So that leaders can stay in power for longer periods

options.label: C
options.text: So that democracies can sink into repressive, authoritarian regimes

options.label: D

title: How the US is destroying young people’s future - Scott Galloway

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument regarding the current state of the economy and society?

options.label: A
options.text: The economy is growing, and everyone is benefiting.

options.label: B
options.text: The economy is stagnant, and no one is benefiting.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a transfer of wealth and opportunity from young to old, and it's causing problems.

options.text: Technology is the main cause of societal issues.

options.label: B
options.text: Artificially constraining supply to create aspiration and scarcity.

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing on vocational training and non-traditional degrees.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They should lose their tax-free status if they don't grow their freshman class faster than the population.

options.label: D
options.text: They should focus on online education.

options.label: A
options.text: It's not providing enough benefits to seniors.

options.label: B
options.text: It's bankrupting the nation and transferring wealth from young to old.

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the capital gains tax deduction.

options.label: B
options.text: Eliminating the capital gains tax deduction.

options.label: C
options.text: Implementing a flat tax rate for all income levels.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's proposal for addressing the issue of algorithmically-elevated content on social media?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Implementing stricter regulations on social media companies.

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging social media companies to self-regulate.

multiple-choice.question: The speaker recommends a change to the way affirmative action is implemented. What is the proposed change?

options.label: A
options.text: Basing affirmative action on income level rather than race or ethnicity.

options.label: B
options.text: Expanding affirmative action to include more groups.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one of the main causes of the decline in young people's well-being and prosperity?

options.label: B
options.text: The increasing cost of higher education.

options.label: D
options.text: The transfer of wealth and opportunity from young to old.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final question to the audience, which he hopes will have more veracity after his presentation?

title: How could so many people support Hitler? - Joseph Lacey

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Adolf Eichmann stand trial in Jerusalem for crimes against humanity?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a high-ranking military officer.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a Nazi official tasked with organizing the transport of European Jews to ghettos and concentration camps.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a spy working for the German secret police.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a politician who opposed the Nazi regime.

options.label: A
options.text: She was a German non-Jew who supported the Nazi regime.

options.label: B
options.text: She was a German Jew who fled her homeland in 1933 after being briefly imprisoned by the German secret police.

options.label: C
options.text: She was a French philosopher who studied the rise of totalitarianism in Germany.

options.label: D
options.text: She was an American philosopher who opposed the Nazi regime.

multiple-choice.question: According to Hannah Arendt, what are the three facets of the human condition?
What did Hannah Arendt believe was under attack in modern societies?
What did Hannah Arendt argue was the fertile ground for totalitarian regimes?

options.label: A
options.text: Societies that value individual freedom and critical thinking

options.label: B
options.text: Societies that prioritize economic growth and technological development

options.label: C
options.text: Societies that isolate individuals and make it dangerous to publicly engage as freethinking political agents

options.label: D
options.text: Societies that value open dialogue and critical self-reflection

multiple-choice.question: What did Hannah Arendt call the phenomenon of ordinary people willingly accepting their societal role, even when it contributes to genocide?
According to Hannah Arendt, what is the only way to confront moral problems?

options.label: A
options.text: Through critical thinking and self-reflective internal dialogue

options.label: B
options.text: Through obedience to authority and tradition

options.label: C
options.text: Through economic growth and technological development

options.label: D
options.text: Through social alienation and inhibition of human freedom

multiple-choice.question: What did Hannah Arendt believe was necessary to foster critical thinking and self-reflection?

options.label: A
options.text: The creation of formal and informal forums for open conversations about shaping our collective future

options.label: B
options.text: The suppression of individual freedom and critical thinking

options.label: C
options.text: The prioritization of economic growth and technological development

options.label: D
options.text: The isolation of individuals from their neighbors and sense of self

multiple-choice.question: What did Hannah Arendt believe was our greatest weapon against the threats of modernity?

options.label: B
options.text: Critical thinking and self-reflective internal dialogue

options.label: C
options.text: Social alienation and inhibition of human freedom

title: If you're an adult mayfly you'll probably die before the end of this video - Luke M. Jacobus

multiple-choice.question: According to Brother David, what is the connection between happiness and gratefulness?

options.label: C
options.text: There is no connection between happiness and gratefulness.

options.label: D
options.text: Happiness and gratefulness are the same thing.

options.label: C
options.text: A gift that is both valuable and truly given to us.

options.label: B
options.text: By becoming aware that every moment is a given moment.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring the difficulties in life.

options.label: B
options.text: We cannot be grateful for everything, but we can be grateful in every given moment.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: We should never be grateful for anything.

multiple-choice.question: What is the simple method that Brother David suggests for living gratefully?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can rest and relax.

options.label: B
options.text: So we can reflect on our past.

options.label: C
options.text: So we can miss the opportunity.

options.label: D
options.text: So we can get quiet and build stop signs into our lives.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we open our hearts to the opportunities, according to Brother David?

options.label: B
options.text: We become grateful and willing to share.

options.label: A
options.text: It makes us fearful and violent.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes us act out of a sense of scarcity.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes us willing to share and respectful to everybody.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes us selfish and greedy.

multiple-choice.question: What does Brother David suggest is needed to create a grateful world?

options.label: A
options.text: A power pyramid with a strong leader.

options.label: B
options.text: A networking of smaller groups who know and interact with one another.

options.label: C
options.text: A world with no differences between people.

options.label: D
options.text: A world with no challenges or difficulties.

multiple-choice.question: According to Brother David, what is the ultimate goal of living gratefully?

options.label: B

What is the name of the program mentioned in the transcript that offers favorable tax treatment for investing in designated distressed and low-income areas?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow companies to pollute without consequences

multiple-choice.question: Which industry is responsible for consuming 70% of all the water used every year, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: We need to invest more in water infrastructure

options.label: B
options.text: We need to develop new technologies to solve the problem

options.label: C
options.text: We need to hold polluters accountable and take action

options.label: D

title: The rise and fall of the Maya Empire’s most powerful city - Geoffrey E. Braswell

multiple-choice.question: What year is mentioned as the time when Lord K'ak' Upakal may have observed the bustling city of Chichen Itza?

What was the primary challenge faced by many Yucatecan cities, including Chichen Itza, in terms of water supply?
What feature of the land surrounding Chichen Itza provided an abundant supply of fresh groundwater?
What was the estimated population of Chichen Itza at its height?
What was the focus of Chichen Itza's government after the death of Lord K'ak' Upakal?
What was the primary purpose of the round temple built in Chichen Itza?

options.label: B
options.text: To worship the feathered serpent god

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the central deity worshipped in Chichen Itza?
What event led to the decline of Chichen Itza's population and eventual replacement by Mayapan as the principal city of Yucatan?
What was the status of Chichen Itza when the Spanish arrived centuries after its decline?

options.label: B
options.text: A small, local capital of a Maya province

title: Does math have a major flaw? - Jacqueline Doan and Alex Kazachek

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mathematical concept where a ball is divided into an infinite number of boxes, recombined into five sections, and then reassembled into two identical copies of the original ball?
What is the foundation of every mathematical system?
What is the purpose of axioms in mathematics?

options.label: C
options.text: To declare basic statements as true and make deductions from them

multiple-choice.question: What is the Axiom of Choice, and when is it typically used?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an axiom that implies the existence of only one parallel line, and it is used in geometry

options.label: B
options.text: It is an axiom that allows for the selection of elements from sets, and it is typically used in proofs

options.label: C
options.text: It is an axiom that states that adding zero to a number has no effect, and it is used in arithmetic

options.label: D
options.text: It is an axiom that implies the existence of multiple parallel lines, and it is used in hyperbolic geometry

multiple-choice.question: Why is the Axiom of Choice necessary in the Banach-Tarski paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows for the selection of distinguishable marbles from infinite boxes

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows for the selection of indistinguishable marbles from infinite boxes

options.label: C
options.text: Because it implies the existence of only one parallel line

options.label: D
options.text: Because it states that adding zero to a number has no effect

multiple-choice.question: Why do mathematicians not reject the Axiom of Choice despite its counterintuitive results?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is not load-bearing for any important results in mathematics

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is only used in the Banach-Tarski paradox

options.label: C
options.text: Because it leads to some impractical results, but also to extremely practical ones

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not necessary in mathematics

multiple-choice.question: What fields of mathematics rely heavily on the Axiom of Choice?
What is the significance of the Banach-Tarski paradox in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that mathematics is flawed and contradictory

options.label: B
options.text: It demonstrates the tension between mathematics and our experience of reality

options.label: C
options.text: It proves that the Axiom of Choice is false

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that mathematics is only useful for practical applications

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between axioms and mathematical systems?

options.label: A
options.text: Axioms are the foundation of every mathematical system, and different axioms can lead to different systems

options.label: B
options.text: Axioms are theorems that are proven within a mathematical system

options.label: C
options.text: Axioms are only used in certain mathematical systems, such as geometry

options.label: D
options.text: Axioms are not necessary in mathematical systems

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's perspective on the nature of mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: Mathematics is a fixed and absolute truth

options.label: B
options.text: Mathematics is a way to model our physical universe, but also allows us to explore abstract mathematical universes

options.label: C
options.text: Mathematics is only useful for practical applications

options.label: D
options.text: Mathematics is a human construct and has no objective truth

options.label: C
options.text: It changes ocean chemistry, making the sea more acidic

options.label: D

What is the name of the expedition led by the speaker to explore and protect the ocean?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Picture a perfect society. What does it look like? - Joseph Lacey

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "veil of ignorance" in John Rawls' thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sense of competition among citizens

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that citizens prioritize their own interests

options.label: C
options.text: To blind citizens to certain information about each other and themselves

options.label: D
options.text: To promote a sense of hierarchy in society

multiple-choice.question: According to Rawls, what is the primary goal of his "original position" thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify principles that support a realistic utopia

multiple-choice.question: What is Rawls' critique of free market philosophies and welfare capitalism?

options.label: A
options.text: They lead to a more equal distribution of wealth and power

options.label: B
options.text: They promote social justice and equality

options.label: C
options.text: They lead to unjust accumulations of wealth and power

options.label: D
options.text: They are too focused on social welfare

multiple-choice.question: What is the "difference principle" in Rawls' theory of justice?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are acceptable if they benefit the most advantaged citizens

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are only acceptable if they benefit the least advantaged citizens

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are never acceptable

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are irrelevant to social justice

multiple-choice.question: What is Rawls' proposed model for achieving a just society?
According to Rawls, what is the importance of equal access to education and healthcare in a just society?

options.label: A
options.text: They are necessary for the accumulation of wealth and power

options.label: B
options.text: They are irrelevant to social justice

options.label: C
options.text: They are essential for ensuring equal opportunities and liberties

options.label: D
options.text: They are only necessary for the most disadvantaged citizens

multiple-choice.question: Who is one of the philosophers who has critiqued Rawls' work, arguing that the difference principle unfairly tethers society's progress to the status of the worst-off?
What is one of the real-life consequences of Rawls' thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: The promotion of free market philosophies

options.label: C
options.text: The inspiration of countless political philosophers, activists, and policymakers to work towards social and political equality

options.label: D
options.text: The justification of existing social structures

multiple-choice.question: What is Rawls' proposed solution to reduce the influence of wealth on politics?

options.label: A
options.text: Limits on campaign spending and political contributions

options.label: C
options.text: The elimination of campaign spending and political contributions

options.label: D
options.text: The promotion of wealthy donors in politics

multiple-choice.question: According to Rawls, what is the importance of the "basic liberties" in a just society?

options.label: A
options.text: They are necessary for the accumulation of wealth and power

options.label: B
options.text: They are irrelevant to social justice

options.label: C
options.text: They are essential for ensuring that citizens can pursue their goals and live according to their own wills

options.label: D
options.text: They are only necessary for the most disadvantaged citizens

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Adolf Hitler die, and the Third Reich begin to collapse?

options.text: His expertise in developing the world's first long-range ballistic missile

options.label: C
options.text: His involvement in the development of chemical weapons

options.text: His connections to the Soviet Union

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were willing to work for low wages

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They indicated that incriminating information like Nazi affiliations or suspected war crimes could be disregarded

options.label: D

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Who were some of the prominent voices that criticized Operation Paperclip?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The launch of the first US satellite

options.label: C
options.text: The design of the Saturn V rocket

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of the Space Shuttle program

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the criticisms of Operation Paperclip?

options.label: C
options.text: That it allowed former Nazis to work in sensitive national security positions

options.label: D
options.text: That it did not recruit enough scientists

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate goal of Operation Paperclip, according to the US government?

options.label: A
options.text: To punish former Nazis for their war crimes

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the Soviet Union from acquiring German brainpower

options.label: D
options.text: To promote international cooperation in science and technology
